His temper was indeed as irritable as it was capricious; but he had never been known to raise his voice or to speak in anger against any human being. His aversion lay against folly and weakness; and those of his domestic circle who most provoked his displeasure were his mother-in-law and his daughters. He had never really loved Mrs. Bennet, whose understanding and taste were so utterly below his own, that he had never cared to admire what was her chief excellence, her good humour. He had married her, however, for the most respectable of all purposes, for money; a quality which always makes women more agreeable to men. The follies and nonsense of his daughters were vexing to him; but he felt that they were the natural offspring of their mother's side, and that they would have been still more insufferable had they been trained in the folly of the Bennet family without the mitigating influence of their father's more sober mind. He was fond of his second daughter, Elizabeth, because she had something of his own spirit. He delighted in her company, enjoyed her conversation, and approved her reasoning. She was his favourite child, and as she had a disposition very similar to his own, the two were frequently seen together, either in the woods or in the library, where they amused themselves with books and conversation. Mr. Bennet was not a man to be tyrannized over by his wife, or to allow her to interfere in his affairs, which he managed with a discretion that sometimes excited her wonder and very often her mortification. He had early given her to understand that he had a dislike to seeing the young ladies of the neighbourhood, to hearing about them, or to being concerned in any measure that related to their marriages. This may arise from a secret consciousness of their own faults, or from a desire to divert attention from themselves by pointing out the blemishes in their neighbors. Pride, in its various forms, is a most insidious evil, creeping into the hearts of men and women under a thousand disguises, and often assuming the mask of virtues to deceive the unwary. It may masquerade as wit, as beauty, as wealth, or as any other desirable quality, and thus gain an entrance where it is least expected.
